Beyond the resort, you'll find supermarkets, restaurants, international schools, and private clinics. The location represents a 40% savings compared to Spanish island markets, making it an intelligent choice for discerning buyers.

faqs.question: Can foreigners buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners can freely purchase property in Spain without citizenship requirements. EU and non-EU citizens have equal rights to property ownership. You will need to obtain a Spanish tax identification number (NIE) and complete standard purchase procedures. Our team can guide you through the entire legal process.

faqs.question: What are the costs of buying property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Beyond the purchase price, expect additional costs: transfer tax (6-10%), notary fees (0.5-1%), property registration fees (0.1%), and legal fees (typically 1-2%). Mortgage fees and surveyor costs may apply if financing. Total acquisition costs typically range from 8-13% of the property price. We provide detailed cost breakdowns for each transaction.

faqs.question: Do I need a visa to buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Purchasing property does not automatically grant visa rights. However, Spain offers investment-based visa programs, including the Non-Lucrative Visa and Golden Visa for significant property investments (€500,000+). We recommend consulting with immigration specialists regarding visa requirements based on your nationality and circumstances.

faqs.question: How much are property taxes in Spain?
faqs.answer: Property taxes in Spain include: annual IBI tax (local property tax, typically 0.4-1.1% of cadastral value), which is modest; and wealth tax (impuesto sobre el patrimonio) if applicable based on total assets. Rental income is subject to personal income tax. Spain also offers favorable non-resident taxation options. Exact amounts vary by location and circumstances.
